When Metal Gear Solid released in 1998 it
was met with universal acclaim all around

the world and swiftly made its way to be widely
regarding as one of the most popular video

games of all time, a honour that the title
still holds now, over twenty years later.

One aspect of the game that critics have especially
praised is the title’s gripping story, characters

and overall world that the game takes place
in.

But, did you know that, behind the scenes,
MGS1’s English translation has actually

been a pretty controversial topic and even
led to the game being completely retranslated
for the Nintendo GameCube Twin Snakes remake?

The game’s localizer has spoke in-depth
about this subject last month, in a self-written
article published on the website Polygon.

Jeremy Blaustein is the localizer responsible
for many popular games released in the 90s

and early 2000s, including Castlevania: Symphony
of the Night and Silent Hill 2 - 4.

Before being hired for Metal Gear, Blaustein
already had a history of working for series

creator Hideo Kojima, with him helping as
the localization supervisor on Snatcher.

In the article, Blaustein recalls the great
difficulties he experienced translating the
game for Western audiences.

The scope of the game was massive and he also
explains how the state of video game localization
back then was barely in its infancy.

There were hardly any frames of reference
in other works for him to use to help him

and there was, of course, no Wikipeadia, Reddit
or YouTube.

He recalls how he worked from home in a tiny
office for 8 months, whilst his kids played

and cried 3 feet away, and this was under
a contract that wouldn’t see him paid until

the job was fully complete – meaning money
was a huge issue.

The stress had him on diazepam, which is also
ironically the same drug that Snake can take

during the game to help stop his hands from
shaking whilst aiming.

However, despite these conditions, Blaustein
felt great inspiration in that he was working

on something special and was determined to
see the job through and make it perfect.
Localization is by no means an easy task though.

Kojima is a celebrated writer but his works
are by no means simple – often combining

complex subjects such as social issues, politics,
psychology, philosophy, science and pretty

much any other subject you can think of thrown
into the mix.

The Japanese language is inherently vastly
different to English.

For instance, the sentence structure in Japanese
is the complete opposite of English and then

you combine this with the cinematic nature
of the game and the dramatic cut-scenes that

have to synch up perfectly with what is being
spoken.

Alongside these issues, Blaustein felt, as
he still feels, that localization should be
more than just translation.

He wanted to try and capture the same meaning
and feeling that he believed Kojima was aiming

for, but to do that for Western audiences,
he felt some tweaks were necessary.

This led to some changes to terms and dialogue,
under the impression that this would help

it all sound more natural and how actual soldiers
would sound.

For example, in the Japanese version, there
is no “codec”, which is now a term that

is synonymous with the series and its wireless
method of communication used between Snake
and his allies.

Instead, the Japanese version simply called
this “musenki” (無線機).

This would translate into English to the much
less imaginative “wireless transceiver”.

But, Blaustein had come across the term “codec”
and thought it would fit the tone of the game
well and so put it in.

This is also the case for the term OSP, or
on-site procurement, where weapons and items

must be acquired from within the enemy base
due to not wanting to leave any trace.

This isn’t real military jargon but Blaustein
felt is sounded official.

The Japanese version however simply calls
this “genchi chōtatsu” (現地調達)

, which could be translated into “acquiring
locally”.

Not wanting things to feel too stiff for US
audiences, Blaustein also added or tweaked
little bits of dialogue here and there too.

In the original, Campbell only says to Snake
“I’m not a colonel anymore”, whilst

in Blaustein’s English translation, he says
“I’m not a colonel anymore, just a retired
old warhorse.”

When the job was complete though, Blaustein
expresses that he really felt that he did

a good job on it and tried his best to stay
in the mind of Kojima as much as possible.

Then, this sentiment was reiterated back by
the team at Konami and even Kojima himself
when it was all shipped back to Japan.

In fact, Kojima liked it so much that when
it came time for a special Japanese-only re-release

version of the game, dubbed Metal Gear Solid:
Integral, he wanted to include the English
voice track in it.

This version of the game adds various updates
and bonuses and only contains the English
voices with Japanese text.

This is a very unusual situation for a game’s
English translation to be later put in and

it was with this where all of the problems
appeared.

You see, when Kojima and his team started
to go through the game line by line and matching

the Japanese text with the voices, the differences
started to become made apparent.

Kojima, who is widely regarded as being a
video game auteur, wasn’t happy that his

work had been changed around and it was here
where it was clear that he wanted a very direct
literal translation.

So, Kojima was then put in a position where
he had to retranslate Blaustein’s dialogue
back into Japanese for the Integral version.

Kojima then severed all ties with Blaustein
and all future games in the series would be

translated much more word for word to the
Japanese original.

Also, like mentioned earlier, for the GameCube
Twin Snakes remake, the English translation,

including the voice acting, was redone to
make it more faithful.

In the remake Snake says “I’m just a guy
who can only find meaning on the battlefield”,

in Blaustein’s version though, this was
a tweaked with him instead saying “I’m
just a man who’s good at what he does.
Killing.”

Whilst normally the meaning would largely
stay intact, sometimes there would be more

subtle meaning in Kojima’s original words
that could be lost.

Another example from the remake is during
Psycho Mantis death scene, where his last

words in the Japanese version and the more
faithful remake are: “This is the first

time … I’ve ever used my power to help
someone.
It’s strange … such a … nostalgic feeling.”

Blaustein felt that “nostalgic” was a
bit of an odd term for English players and

so his version changed this to “it feels
… kind of … nice.”

However, Kojima intended on using the term
“nostalgic” specifically, due to it being

a reference to Mantis’ mother, who died
whilst giving birth to him, and this meaning
wasn’t conveyed in the English version.

The article ends with Blaustein saying:
“Looking back on the whole thing, yes, there

were mistakes, and bad choices as well as
successful ones.
But that’s art.

Translation isn’t science, and after 20
years of Metal Gear Solid’s success, I think
I must have done a pretty good job.”
